q1.question: What is Verifactu and why does it affect me?
q1.answer: Verifactu is the new AEAT regulation to combat tax fraud through invoicing software. From July 2027, all freelancers and SMEs who invoice B2B (to other businesses) must use approved software that generates a QR code per invoice and sends information to the tax authority in real time. Goal: prevent fake invoices and record manipulation. If you invoice with Word, Excel, or non-approved software, your B2B invoices will be illegal. It affects you if: you're a freelancer or SME, you invoice less than €6M/year, and your clients are businesses (B2B). Solution: use software like Invoo that already complies with Verifactu. If you wait until June 2027, you'll be rushed and stressed. If you start now, you'll arrive calm.

q2.question: Is Invoo ready for Verifactu?
q2.answer: Yes, from day 1. Invoo automatically generates the Verifactu QR code on each invoice and handles submission to the AEAT through our API. You invoice normally, we handle the technical part. When Verifactu becomes mandatory in July 2027, you don't have to do anything: your Invoo already complies. No updates, no migrations, no surprises. Plus, we export audit evidence and show the status of each invoice (submitted, accepted, rejected). 82% of SMEs aren't prepared for Verifactu. You will be.

q3.question: Can I continue using Excel or Word to invoice?
q3.answer: Until July 2027, yes. But after that, not for B2B invoices (businesses). Verifactu prohibits non-approved software for invoicing between businesses. You can continue using Word for B2C invoices (individuals without business activity), but you'll waste time: 10 minutes per manual invoice vs 30 seconds with Invoo. Plus, Word doesn't calculate VAT automatically, doesn't generate QR, doesn't connect with your accountant. Many people say 'my Word has worked for 8 years'. But from July 2027, it won't comply with Verifactu for B2B. Better to migrate now without pressure than wait until the last minute.

q4.question: What are the penalties for not complying with Verifactu?
q4.answer: Fines of up to €50,000 for not using approved software or manipulating tax records. The tax authority can audit your invoices and if they detect you're using Word/Excel after July 2027 for B2B, they'll sanction you. Serious violations include: invoices without Verifactu QR, non-approved software, manipulation of accounting records. It's not an empty threat: Verifactu exists because there is fraud. The tax authority is serious. The good news is that avoiding it is easy: use software like Invoo that complies automatically. €10.90/month is much less than a €50,000 fine. Do the math.

Compared to Holded (€100+/month for 4 users) or Factorial (€4.5/user/month = €18/month, without full invoicing), Invoo is cheaper and focused. €19.90/month = €5 per user. Less than what you lose on an invoice error.

q1.question: How long does it take to create an invoice with Invoo?
q1.answer: 30 seconds if the client is already registered. Open Invoo, select client, enter concept and amount, save. Done. Invoo calculates VAT and withholding tax automatically, generates PDF with Verifactu QR, and sends by email if you want. First invoice of the day: 30 seconds. Tenth invoice: 25 seconds (you've got the rhythm). Compared to Word (10 minutes: open template, update data, calculate taxes, save PDF, send), or Excel (5-8 minutes), or Holded (2 minutes navigating complex menus), Invoo is brutal. Real speed, measured, verifiable. Time it yourself.

q2.question: Does Invoo support international invoicing and multi-currency?
q2.answer: Yes. Create invoices in EUR, USD, GBP, or other currencies, Invoo applies VAT rules automatically based on destination country (intra-EU, extra-EU, reverse charge). For UK clients post-Brexit: invoice without VAT with 'Reverse charge' mention. For EU clients with valid intra-EU tax ID: no VAT, but register in form 349. For clients outside EU: no VAT, export. All automatic. You enter the client's country, Invoo decides which rule to apply. No errors, no consulting your accountant each time. David, a tech freelancer with clients in London and Berlin, invoices in 30 seconds without thinking about VAT. That's how it works.

q3.question: Can I automate recurring invoices?
q3.answer: Yes. Set up a recurring invoice (client, concept, amount, frequency: monthly, quarterly, annual), Invoo generates and sends it automatically each period. Perfect for Miguel, who invoices €5,000/month to the same client for 2 years. Set it once, forget about it. Every 1st of the month, Invoo creates the invoice, sends PDF to the client, notifies the accountant. Miguel doesn't touch anything. Saves 15 minutes per month. If one month the amount changes, edit punctually. If you want to pause, pause. Automation that's not scary: you control, Invoo executes.

q4.question: How do quotes work? Can I convert them to invoices?
q4.answer: Yes, in 1 click. Create a quote with client, line items, discounts. Send to client. Client accepts (by email or digital signature if configured). Enter Invoo, open accepted quote, 'Convert to invoice' button. Done. No rewriting, no copy-pasting, no errors. Automatic numbering, updated date, status changes to 'Invoice issued'. This saves 5-10 minutes per accepted quote. If you make 5 quotes per month and 3 become invoices, you save 15-30 minutes. Plus, your accountant sees quotes and invoices linked: total traceability.

q5.question: Can I apply discounts on invoices?
q5.answer: Yes, by line or global. Line discount: enter product/service €100, apply 10% discount, Invoo shows €90 and calculates VAT on €90. Global discount: enter 3 services (total €500), apply 15% global discount, Invoo calculates on €425. Useful for promotions, VIP clients, negotiations. Compared to Word (calculate discount manually = errors) or software that charges for 'discount module', Invoo includes it free. Discounts are part of professional invoicing, not an extra. They're there, use them when you want.

q6.question: If I have a team (SME), how do I know who created each invoice?
q6.answer: Admin dashboard shows 'Created by' column in invoice list. Filter by user, see all of María's invoices, or Juan's, or yours. Useful for internal audit (who invoiced client X?), for commercial tracking (how much did each salesperson invoice this month?), for control (did someone invoice without authorization?). Your accountant also sees this info in their dashboard. Compared to shared Excel where nobody knows who edited what, or Holded where this info is buried in menus, Invoo puts it front and center. Laura, agency owner with 4 employees, uses it for quarterly bonuses: exports invoices by user, calculates commissions. Total transparency.

q7.question: Does Invoo calculate VAT and withholding tax automatically?
q7.answer: Yes, always. Enter gross amount (€1,000), Invoo adds 21% VAT (€210) and applies 15% withholding tax (-€150) if applicable. Result: invoice total €1,060. You enter €1,000, Invoo does the rest. No calculator, no Excel formulas, no errors. If invoicing professional services: 15% withholding (7% if you're a new freelancer). If selling products: 21% VAT, no withholding. If exporting outside EU: no VAT, no withholding. All according to current AEAT regulations. Impossible to make mistakes. Carmen, 48, invoicing with Word since 2015, had to pay €300 to the tax authority for a VAT error. With Invoo: zero errors.

q8.question: Can I record expenses in Invoo?
q8.answer: Yes. Record expenses (concept, amount, VAT, category: supplies, software, transport), upload receipt photo or received invoice PDF. Your accountant sees your expenses in their dashboard, exports them for quarterly deductions. Useful for: keeping monthly track of spending, having centralized receipts (goodbye phone photo folder), facilitating your accountant's work (they see expense + receipt in same place). It's not full accounting (that's what your accountant with their software is for), but it's sufficient recording for freelancers. David records 8-12 expenses per month (Notion, Figma, client coffees), his accountant downloads them in seconds. No WhatsApps, no lost photos.

q1.question: How can my accountant manage multiple clients with Invoo?
q1.answer: Your accountant accesses a single panel where they see all their clients who use Invoo. They can filter by client, download consolidated invoices, export CSV by quarter, manage Verifactu for everyone in one place. If your accountant has 50 clients on Invoo, they see all 50 from one dashboard. No logging into 50 different accounts, no chasing documents via WhatsApp. Each client invites the accountant from their account, the accountant accepts once, and has perpetual access (until the client revokes). This allows small accounting firms (2-5 employees) to compete with online services offering technology + personal relationship. Ana, accounting firm owner in Valencia with 200 clients, manages 3x more clients without hiring thanks to Invoo.

q2.question: Will my clients have to pay to use Invoo?
q2.answer: Yes, but very little: €10.90/month freelancers, €19.90/month SMEs. Much less than they'd pay an online accountant service (€30+/month) and with the advantage of keeping you as their trusted advisor. You offer Invoo as part of your service: 'Use this tool, I see everything automatically, you make my work easier and I save you hours consolidating invoices'. Many accountants negotiate: 'If you use Invoo, I'll reduce my fees €15/month because you save me work'. Client pays €10.90 Invoo, saves €15 on accounting, gains €4 + time + peace of mind. Win-win. Invoo isn't competition, it's an ally.

q3.question: Does Invoo offer white-label for accountants?
q3.answer: Yes, in Enterprise plan (direct contact). White-label means: your client sees your brand (your logo, your name), not Invoo. You offer 'Invoicing Portal [Your Firm]' powered by Invoo. Client uses software, thinks it's yours, you control the relationship. Price depends on number of clients. Example: accounting firm with 300 clients, €299/month flat. Client pays nothing, you include cost in your fees or charge €5 extra/client/month. Perfect for medium-sized accounting firms that want to compete with online services without losing their brand. If you have 150+ clients and are interested, contact us. We set up in 2 weeks.

q4.question: Will my clients (traditional freelancers) know how to use Invoo?
q4.answer: Yes. We designed Invoo for Carmen: 48 years old, 8 years using Word, technology isn't her thing. If Carmen can, your clients can. Interface without complicated menus, only the essentials. Many accountants do onboarding: first invoice together on video call (10 minutes), client learns, done. After that they invoice on their own. If they get stuck, Invoo support responds (or you help if you prefer to maintain control). 95% of traditional freelancer clients who try Invoo adopt it. The remaining 5% go back to Word... until Verifactu forces them in July 2027. Better to onboard now without pressure.

q5.question: Does Invoo replace my accounting software?
q5.answer: No, it complements it. Professional accounting software is for complete accounting, filing tax returns, multi-company management. Invoo is for client invoicing. Your workflow: client invoices in Invoo → you see invoices in Invoo dashboard → export CSV → import to your accounting software for formal accounting. Invoo doesn't replace your internal ERP, it facilitates client data capture. Without Invoo, you receive invoices via WhatsApp/email, type them manually into your system. With Invoo, you download clean CSV, import automatically. Save 2-3 hours per client per quarter. That scales: 100 clients = 200-300h saved/quarter. You can manage more clients or lower price and win volume.

q6.question: How does Invoo compete with online accountant services?
q6.answer: Invoo doesn't compete with you, it helps you compete against online services. Online accountants charge €30/month and offer technology, but without personal relationship, without trusted advice. You offer: 10 years of personal relationship, you know their business, proactive advice, PLUS Invoo technology (€10.90/month client or €0 if white-label included in your fees). Client pays €80-100/month to you (traditional accounting + Invoo) vs €30/month online service. Difference of €50-70, but online is impersonal, they don't call to warn about deductions, they don't know you. You do. Invoo is your secret weapon: you modernize without losing what makes you valuable. Ana, accounting firm in Valencia, recovered 15 clients who had left for online services by offering them Invoo + her expertise. It works.

q1.question: Where is my data stored?
q1.answer: On servers in Europe (AWS Frankfurt or similar), complying with GDPR. Your invoices, clients, and tax data are encrypted in transit (HTTPS) and at rest (AES-256). We don't sell data to third parties, we don't do marketing with your info, we don't share with anyone except your accountant (if you authorize it). Automatic daily backups, disaster recovery guaranteed. Security certificates audited annually. Compared to Excel on Dropbox (no encryption), or pirated software (where is your data?), Invoo is bank-level security. Your data is yours, always.

q2.question: Who can see my invoices and expenses?
q2.answer: Only you, your team (if SME), and your accountant (if you invited them). No one else. Not even Invoo as a company can see your invoice content (they're encrypted). Support employees only access if you open a ticket and authorize (to resolve a technical problem). No third-party access, no weird integrations that leak data. If you revoke access from your accountant, they lose access instantly. Absolute control. This is critical: your competition can't see your clients, the tax authority sees nothing except what Verifactu sends (which is mandatory by law), no one spies. Real privacy.

q3.question: Can I export my data?
q3.answer: Yes, everything. Export invoices in PDF (individual or batch), CSV with complete listing (client, date, amount, VAT, withholding, status), expenses in CSV, clients in CSV. Useful for: switching software (I hope not, but it's your right), doing analysis in Excel, delivering to external auditor, personal backup. Export without limits, no extra cost. Your data is yours, not Invoo hostages. GDPR requires portability, we comply gladly. 'Export all' button downloads ZIP with PDFs + CSVs. 2 minutes, done.

q4.question: What happens to my invoices if I cancel my account?
q4.answer: You have 30 days to export everything before permanent deletion. Cancel on January 1, you can download invoices until January 31. After that, we delete your data permanently (GDPR: right to be forgotten). That's why we recommend exporting immediately when canceling. Invoo sends reminder email 7 days before deletion. We don't keep your invoices in 'dead archive' forever: you cancel, export, we delete. Clean, respectful, legal. If you cancel by mistake and 30 days pass, we can't recover (backups are overwritten). Export first, cancel second.

q5.question: Does Invoo have two-factor authentication (2FA)?
q5.answer: Yes. Activate 2FA from settings, use authenticator app (Google Authenticator, Authy). Each login requires temporary code plus password. Protects against password hacks, phishing, unauthorized access. Critical if you manage company invoicing with multiple users or sensitive data. Quipu doesn't have 2FA (serious breach). Contasimple had hacked accounts. Invoo: 2FA from day 1, free, strongly recommended. Activate it, sleep well. If you lose access to authenticator app, support helps you with recovery codes (saved when activating 2FA). Security without compromise.

serviceDescription.title: Service Description
serviceDescription.content:
Invoo is a digital platform aimed at professionals and businesses that allows issuing and managing electronic invoices, generating PDF versions, numbering them correctly, and incorporating the official QR code when the User operates under Verifactu. It also transforms each invoice into an Invoicing Record in accordance with Royal Decree 1007/2023, including the metadata, chaining, and hashes required by regulations.

The Service also enables automatic submission of these records to the Tax Administration through an external tax connectivity provider (currently Verifacti (Bilbabit, S.L.)) acting as a technical intermediary. Transmission may occur in real-time or within the timeframes permitted by regulations, and the Administration may accept or reject the submitted records, something entirely beyond Invoo's control.

Additionally, the Platform allows managing clients, products, and services, storing data and automating recurring information. It offers an expense recording system through uploading and classifying receipts or invoices, as well as exporting such data for gestorías. It also generates preliminary tax calculations such as estimates for models 130 or 303, although these calculations are merely indicative and do not constitute tax advice or a filed declaration. Finally, the User can share information with their gestoría through a secure link that allows consulting invoices, expenses, and the status of Invoicing Records.

serviceNature.title: Nature of the Service
serviceNature.content: Invoo is software provided under a SaaS model accessible entirely online without the need for local installation. It does not act as a gestoría, tax advisor, or representative of the User before the AEAT. The Service does not replace the review or analysis by the User or their advisor, nor does it guarantee by itself full compliance with all applicable tax obligations.

q1.question: What are the current VAT rates in Spain in 2026?
q1.answer: In Spain there are four VAT rates: the standard 21% which applies to most products and services; the reduced 10% for food, transport and hospitality; the super-reduced 4% for essential products such as bread, milk and medicines; and 0% for exempt services such as healthcare and education.

q2.question: How do I calculate VAT for an invoice?
q2.answer: To calculate VAT, multiply the base amount by the VAT rate divided by 100. For example, for a base of €100 with 21% VAT: 100 × 0.21 = €21 VAT. The invoice total would be €121. Our calculator does this calculation automatically.

q3.question: How do I extract VAT from a price that already includes it?
q3.answer: To extract VAT from a final price, divide the total by 1 plus the VAT rate. For example, for a price of €121 with 21% VAT: 121 ÷ 1.21 = €100 base amount. The VAT would be €21. Select 'Extract VAT from total' in our calculator to perform this calculation.

q4.question: What VAT should I apply to my services as a freelancer?
q4.answer: Most professional services are taxed at 21% standard VAT. However, some services have reduced rates or are exempt. For example, healthcare services are exempt, as is regulated training. Consult with your accountant if you have doubts about your specific activity.

q5.question: When do I have to file quarterly VAT (form 303)?
q5.answer: Freelancers and SMBs must file form 303 quarterly: by April 20 (Q1), July 20 (Q2), October 20 (Q3) and January 30 of the following year (Q4). In the form you declare the output VAT (charged) minus the input VAT (paid), and pay or offset the difference.

q6.question: What is input VAT and output VAT?
q6.answer: Output VAT is what you charge your customers on your sales invoices. Input VAT is what you pay on invoices from your suppliers and deductible expenses. In the quarterly declaration, you subtract input from output: if the result is positive, you pay; if negative, you can offset or request a refund.

q1.question: How much does a self-employed person pay in 2026?
q1.answer: It depends on your real income. With the 2026 bracket system, the minimum quota is €205/month for low income, and can reach up to €607/month for high income. New self-employed pay only €80/month with Flat Rate, or €0 with Zero Quota in some regions.

q2.question: What is net income?
q2.answer: It's the difference between your gross income and your deductible expenses (office rent, utilities, materials, insurance, etc.). Social Security uses your net income to determine your bracket and contribution base.

q3.question: Can I change my contribution base?
q3.answer: Yes, you can modify your contribution base up to 6 times per year through the RED system or your accountant. This allows you to adjust your quota if your income varies during the year.

q4.question: What is annual regularization?
q4.answer: At the end of the fiscal year, Social Security compares what you contributed with your actual income declared in your tax return. If you over-contributed, they refund the difference. If you under-contributed, you'll have to pay the difference.

q5.question: How do I apply for the Flat Rate?
q5.answer: It's requested when registering as self-employed, by checking the option on form TA.0521. If you're already registered, you can request it as long as you meet the requirements (less than 12 months since registration).

q6.question: What does the self-employed quota cover?
q6.answer: The quota covers: common contingencies (healthcare, sick leave), professional contingencies (work accidents), business cessation (unemployment for self-employed) and professional training. Everything is included in the 31.30-31.50% rate.

q1.question: How is an invoice total with VAT and IRPF calculated?
q1.answer: The invoice total is Base + VAT. The net you receive is: Base + VAT - IRPF. For example: with €1,000 base, 21% VAT and 15% IRPF: Total = 1,000 + 210 = €1,210. Net = 1,210 - 150 = €1,060.

q2.question: On what amount is IRPF withholding applied?
q2.answer: IRPF withholding is applied to the base amount, not the total with VAT. This is important for correctly calculating the net amount to receive.

q3.question: When can I apply the 7% IRPF as a new freelancer?
q3.answer: You can apply the reduced 7% rate during the year you start your activity and the following two years, provided you haven't exercised another professional activity in the previous year. You must communicate this to the payer.

q4.question: Do I need to include IRPF on invoices to individuals?
q4.answer: No. IRPF withholding only applies when invoicing businesses or professionals acting as such. Invoices to individuals don't include IRPF withholding.

q5.question: What VAT rate should I apply on my invoices?
q5.answer: The standard rate is 21% for most professional services. 10% applies to food, passenger transport, hospitality. 4% to basic foods, books, medicines. 0% for exempt services like healthcare and education.

q6.question: Who must apply IRPF withholding on their invoices?
q6.answer: Self-employed professionals registered in IAE section 2 activities (professional activities) when invoicing businesses or professionals. Self-employed with business activities (section 1) generally don't apply withholding.

q1.question: How much should I charge per hour as a freelancer?

q2.question: Why does my hourly rate need to be so high?
q2.answer: As a freelancer, out of every euro you bill, you only take home 50-70 cents net. The rest goes to income tax (19-47%), social security (~€230-530/month in 2026), deductible expenses (20-40%), and non-billable time (vacation, administration, sales). That's why your hourly rate must be 2-3 times your desired 'hourly salary'. And no, it's not that you're charging too much: it's that being self-employed costs a lot.

q3.question: How many billable hours does a freelancer have per year?
q3.answer: Typically between 1,200-1,600 hours annually. If you work 40h/week × 48 weeks (minus 4 vacation) = 1,920 total hours. But of those, 20-40% goes to non-billable tasks: administration, client acquisition, training, internal meetings. That's why 1,400-1,500 actual billable hours is common.

q4.question: Should I include VAT in my hourly rate?
q4.answer: No. VAT (generally 21%) is added to the final price but isn't your income—you must give it to the tax authorities. Your hourly rate should cover: your net salary + income tax + social security + expenses. VAT is separate and neutral (you collect it from clients and pay it to authorities, though you can deduct VAT from your expenses).

q5.question: How do deductible expenses affect my rate?
q5.answer: Expenses reduce your tax base, so you pay less income tax and social security. If you spend 20% of billing on deductible expenses, your tax burden will be lower than if you spend 0%. But be careful: spending just to spend isn't profitable. Only include real and necessary business expenses. This calculator accounts for that expense percentage.

q6.question: Should my rate be the same for all projects?
q6.answer: Not necessarily. You can have a base rate for standard projects and adjust based on: urgency (rush = more expensive), technical complexity, project duration (long contracts may get discounts), client type (large companies vs startups), exclusivity or required availability. The important thing is your weighted average rate covers your total costs.

q7.question: What if my clients say I'm too expensive?
q7.answer: First, verify they're your target audience. If you bill B2B (companies), your €50-80/h rate is normal and profitable for them (you're saving them hiring a €40,000-50,000/year employee). Second, justify the value: don't sell 'hours', sell results. Instead of '€40/h', say 'this project will save you €X per year'. Third, if they still say it's expensive, they're not your client: find another one.

q1.answer: Quarterly: from the 1st to the 20th of April (Q1), July (Q2), October (Q3), and from the 1st to the 30th of January of the following year (Q4). If the deadline falls on a weekend or holiday, it extends to the next business day. There's an option to direct debit the payment, which has a deadline 5 days earlier.

q2.question: What is output VAT and input VAT?
q2.answer: Output VAT is what you charge your customers (you collect it for the tax authority). Input VAT is what you pay to your suppliers. In Form 303 you declare the difference: if you collected more than you paid, you pay the difference; if you paid more, you offset.

q3.question: What expenses can I deduct in Form 303?

q4.question: What happens if the result is negative?

q5.question: Can I request a VAT refund in any quarter?

q6.question: What's the difference between Form 303 and Form 390?

q1.question: What expenses can a freelancer deduct?
q1.answer: Freelancers can deduct necessary expenses for their activity: office supplies, computer equipment, software, office rent, utilities (if working from home), transportation, professional training, insurance, and the self-employed contribution itself. The key is that they're directly related to the activity.

q2.question: What is the 5% hard-to-justify expenses deduction?
q2.answer: It's an automatic 5% deduction on your net income (income minus expenses), capped at €2,000 per year. Only applies in simplified direct estimation regime. It covers small expenses without invoices that are difficult to document.

q3.question: Can I deduct my mobile phone if it's personal and professional?
q3.answer: Yes, but only 50% if it's mixed use. To deduct 100%, you need an exclusively professional line. The tax authority is strict about this and may reject deductions above 50% without justification.

q4.question: What percentage of utilities can I deduct if I work from home?
q4.answer: 30% of the percentage of home used for business. Example: if your office occupies 20% of your home, you can deduct 30% of that 20%, i.e., 6% of total utilities. You must have notified the tax authority of professional use via form 036/037.

q5.question: Do I need an invoice to deduct an expense?
q5.answer: Yes, to deduct VAT you need a complete invoice with all tax details. For IRPF, in some cases a receipt or bank statement suffices, but it's recommended to always request an invoice. The self-employed contribution is justified with the bank statement.

q6.question: Can I deduct business meals?
q6.answer: VAT on meals is NOT deductible when it's client entertainment (Art. 96.1.6º LIVA). However, it IS deductible for business travel expenses (per diem) outside your municipality of residence, as long as they meet IRPF deductibility requirements. The base amount can be deducted for IRPF if justified as a necessary business expense and doesn't exceed 1% of annual revenue. Always keep the invoice and note the business reason.

q1.question: From what income level is it worth creating an SL?
q1.answer: There's no exact figure, it depends on your desired salary and expenses. As a general rule, with net profits (after expenses) above €40,000-50,000 annually, SL is usually more advantageous due to the differential between IRPF (up to 47%) and Corporate Tax (25%). Use the calculator with your real data to know for sure.

q2.question: What is the 15% reduced Corporate Tax rate?
q2.answer: If it's your first SL and you haven't been an administrator of another company in the last 5 years, you can apply 15% Corporate Tax (instead of 25%) during the first 2 fiscal years with profits, on the first €300,000. It's a tax advantage to encourage entrepreneurship.

q3.question: How much does it cost to create and maintain an SL?
q3.answer: Creating an SL costs between €500-1,000 (notary, commercial registry). Annual maintenance includes accountant (€1,800-3,000/year), account filing, corporate tax. Fixed costs are significantly higher than as freelancer (accountant ~€600/year).

q4.question: Can I deduct more expenses in an SL than as freelancer?
q4.answer: Not necessarily. Deductible expenses must be related to the activity in both cases. The difference is in how they're taxed: in SL you first pay Corporate Tax on company profit, then IRPF if you distribute dividends. Allows more flexibility in tax planning.

q5.question: What happens with Social Security in an SL?
q5.answer: As SL administrator you contribute to General SS Regime, not as self-employed. Contributions are higher (company pays ~36%, you ~5% of gross salary), but in return you have better coverage (unemployment, work accidents). Total quota can exceed self-employed.

q6.question: Can I switch from freelancer to SL without deregistering?
q6.answer: Yes, you can create an SL and continue as freelancer temporarily to make the transition. Many entrepreneurs create the SL, gradually transfer the activity, then deregister as self-employed. You can also maintain both if you do different activities.
